claim: If tiger sharks stop swimming, nothing in particular happens to them.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, are obligate ram ventilators, meaning they must continuously swim to pass water over their gills to extract oxygen.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, are obligate ram ventilators, meaning they must continuously swim to pass water over their gills to extract oxygen.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor, suggesting they may have limited buccal pumping ability to move water over their gills without swimming.
These observations of resting tiger sharks are rare and may represent stressed or dying individuals rather than typical behavior.
Even if tiger sharks can briefly stop swimming, prolonged immobility would still lead to oxygen deprivation and suffocation.

supporting.text: If tiger sharks stop swimming, they will suffocate due to lack of oxygen flow over their gills, as they cannot actively pump water like some other fish species.

attacks.text: If tiger sharks stop swimming, they will suffocate due to lack of oxygen flow over their gills, as they cannot actively pump water like some other fish species.
Tiger sharks can survive brief periods without swimming by slowing their metabolism and relying on residual oxygen in the water.
Even brief pauses in swimming significantly reduce oxygen intake, leading to stress and potential suffocation in tiger sharks.
Some observations show tiger sharks resting motionless near ocean currents that passively provide water flow over their gills.
Such resting behavior is rare and only possible in specific high-current environments, not representative of typical tiger shark habitats.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks rely on constant movement to maintain buoyancy and avoid sinking, as they lack a swim bladder like bony fish.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks rely on constant movement to maintain buoyancy and avoid sinking, as they lack a swim bladder like bony fish.
Some shark species can rest on the ocean floor and pump water over their gills without swimming, suggesting tiger sharks might have similar adaptations.
Tiger sharks are obligate ram ventilators, meaning they must keep swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen, unlike some benthic sharks.
Shark buoyancy is also aided by their large, oil-filled livers, which reduce their need for constant swimming to stay afloat.
While shark livers provide some buoyancy, tiger sharks still sink if they stop swimming due to their high muscle density and lack of swim bladder.

supporting.text: In the absence of swimming, tiger sharks would be unable to hunt effectively, as their predatory behavior depends on active movement to locate and pursue prey.

attacks.text: In the absence of swimming, tiger sharks would be unable to hunt effectively, as their predatory behavior depends on active movement to locate and pursue prey.
Tiger sharks can still rely on scavenging or ambush predation if they stop swimming, as they are opportunistic feeders.
Scavenging and ambush predation are less reliable food sources compared to active hunting, which could lead to starvation over time.
Some shark species can enter a state of tonic immobility when stationary, which may reduce their metabolic needs temporarily.
Tonic immobility is typically a stress response and not a sustainable state for prolonged periods, especially for active predators like tiger sharks.
